title: Ashe: Warmother.   Issue #1.  Avail nows!

embed.description: Thousands of years ago, the War of Three Sisters nearly tore the frigid wilds of the Freljord apart.Today, the tribes descended from the three sisters -- the Winter's Claw, the Avarosan, and the Frostguard -- still fight for power and survival.Ashe, daughter of the Avarosan warmother, trains to someday lead her people.Food is scarce in the Freljord.

Yes there is people gifted with elemental magic across runeterra.  I would bet you could find someone with ice elemental magic in the northern mountainous regions of Ionia for example. 

Different regions probably are more or less likely to display particular elemental gifts, based on the magical elements and elemental magics presence in that region.    

And yah, different regions are likely to have different terms for people gifted with elemental magic.

Is there a really distinct difference between a mage and whateve an iceborn is? Or are they the same, or is it more like... a scale, with human on one end, mage on the other, and iceborn in the middle

A mage can mean a lot of things, it's a very general term.   A mage might be an iceborn, or hearthbound with some non-elemental magic connections.    

An Iceborn can be a mage, (Lissandra is) but an Iceborn implies a spiritual connection to the most common elemental magic of the freljord.  

 Iceborn also describes certain abilities above and beyond what a mage might have and are esp strong in cold environments.  They have Superhuman strength, resilience and resistance to cold.   

Case in point, Grena is physically stronger than she looks (much like Thor or Captain America.)     If you fought Grena on a busy NY street she could easily throw a toyota at you, and could probably lift a city bus if it was winter.

Just to be sure, since I think it's heavily implied but maybe it's not stated clearly: is the connection to ice elemental power inherited by bloodline, i.e. do iceborn get born, ore are they somehow *made*? _**Bloodsworn**_ is a term mostly for men.  (It can be used to describe women-- but that would sound odd to a Freljordian).    It denotes the right to make children with, the importance of his potential lineage, and his oath to protect.   (It does not actually mean they are exclusive (a man can be bloodsworn to more than one woman) or even that they are engaged in a sexual relationship-- it simply means that they are publicly stating he should have children, and that he has sworn to protect her and her children with his own life.)

_**Bloodkin**_ is the general term used for oaths from same gender (and usually only between women).   It also is an oath to protect and serve as a younger sibling would (And esp an oath to protect the other woman's children)  but also implies a level of trust within the command structure.  Being the bloodkin of the warmother-- implies a senior warrior --trusted to give orders on the battlefield.   This is often further stratified by being given a specific title:  Battlemaiden, Battlesister etc....     


It's worth noting that a woman would almost never take a bloodsworn who is already sworn to another woman-- unless she first made that other woman her bloodkin, or adopted that woman's children as her own. (If she did not trust the other women to be a bloodkin).  Marriage and oaths can be complicated social affairs-- but are ultimately about making large familial networks. 


Some more of this will be seen in later issues.

This might’ve been lore I missed elsewhere, but what exactly are the Hearthbound? Is it just the bame for a specific class of people in the Freljord? Does it have some connection to Ornn’s former people, the Hearthblood?

Side note: Young blond Ashe is adorable, and, as another said elsewhere, would love to see that be a skin for her in the future.

Funny,  some people are like "Why are you over explaining the Hearthbound in exposition?!" and other people are like, "Wait what exactly are the Hearthbound?"   ....   Sometimes as a writer you can't win.

Hearthbound are regular humans, you and me.   

As opposed to Iceborn, spiritwalkers, fireborn (aka Hearthborn), stormborn, etc...   i.e. the superhuman, magically gifted folk.   

Hearthbound speaks to the fact that we (regular humans) need fire to survive in harsh Freljordian winters.  While spiritwalkers, Iceborn etc... can survive in climates we can't.

Going to ask an obvious question, but having -born in the name means that person has innate elemental magic? Are there a standard amount of elements (fire, water, earth, air), or are there more abstract ones?

Putting on my worldbuilding hat.   

The assumption of elemental magic ruleset is that it is infinitely scalable and malleable.   i.e. Most of what we've focused on for worldbuilding is logic systems rather than classifications.   This way the many teams at riot and many products can build whatever they need... provided they follow the internal logic of the systems.    

So we can assume wind, fire, Ice, water, but it's possible to assume lighting, earth, sand, mist, etc.. etc...  If we are making a new Champion or character for a comic book we want a simple system that doesn't require huge exposition.

So the core idea is that some people and creatures have a transcendental connection to the elements (and the elemental plane). They are empowered by contact with this element (esp pure versions of that element), and they have the ability to wield that element as magic.  

We don't want to make classifications that limit teams.  We want rules that people can "feel" beneath the construction of the world going forward.   (I.e. If you know what an Iceborn is, how much time do I need to spend explaining Stormborn?  Not much right?)
